title: The Importance of Trees
text:
What can Trees Do for People?

Trees provide numerous benefits to people, including:

Improving Air Quality – Trees absorb pollutants (like CO₂, ozone, and particulate matter) and release oxygen.
Reducing Urban Heat – They provide shade and cool the air through evapotranspiration, lowering energy costs.
Enhancing Mental Health – Exposure to trees reduces stress and improves overall well-being.
Boosting Property Values – Homes near trees often have higher market values.
Reducing Flooding – Tree roots absorb rainwater, decreasing runoff and erosion.
Supporting Wildlife – Trees provide habitats for birds, insects, and other urban wildlife.
Encouraging Physical Activity – Green spaces promote walking, jogging, and outdoor recreation.




How Is Income Related to Trees in NYC?

In New York City, tree distribution is often linked to income levels:

Wealthier Neighborhoods Have More Trees – Areas like the Upper East Side and Park Slope have higher tree canopy coverage compared to lower-income areas.
Environmental Inequality – Lower-income neighborhoods (e.g., parts of the Bronx and Brooklyn) tend to have fewer trees, leading to higher heat island effects and poorer air quality.
City Initiatives – NYC’s MillionTreesNYC program (2007-2015) aimed to increase tree equity, but disparities remain.
Health & Economic Impacts – Less tree cover in low-income areas can worsen health outcomes (e.g., asthma rates) and reduce property values.
